definition: to garrison/to stand guard/on garrison duty
to guard/to defend/to keep watch/to abide by the law/to observe (rules or ritual)/nearby/adjoining
to prepare/get ready/to provide or equip

sentences.english: Now it has few inhabitants besides its garrison.
sentences.chinese: 而现在，除了守备部队，在法拉只有很少的居民。

sentences.english: If the wall is low, the moats shallow, and the defenses weak then it can be taken.
sentences.chinese: 如果它的城垣低，战壕浅，守备弱，就能攻下来了。

sentences.english: First the garrison lost the airstrip, which meant it could only be reinforced by parachute.
sentences.chinese: 先是守备部队丢掉了机场跑道，这意味着要加强空投。

sentences.english: The troops came to the relief of the besieged garrison.
sentences.chinese: 军队来援救被围的守备军。

sentences.english: Stormtrooper scout units were usually assigned to garrison posts.
sentences.chinese: 冲锋队侦察兵通常被部署到守备基地中。

sentences.english: Torre said that Phillips' primary advantage over Phelps was based upon defensive considerations.
sentences.chinese: 托老说，小菲被选上的主要优势在于守备上的考量。

sentences.english: Melky Cabrera also had two good games today, on offense and in the field.
sentences.chinese: 小卡今天同样有两场好比赛，打击上和守备上。

sentences.english: Although mostly used as garrison troops, they are sometimes pressed into service in the field.
sentences.chinese: 尽管多用于守备城市，但有时亦出外作战。

sentences.english: In the spring of 1944, each regiment created a training battalion.
sentences.chinese: 1944年春，每个国境守备团开始增设一个训练营。

definition: the local commander/provincial governor (in Qing and Ming times)
